I. PROINOV and N. M. NESHEV Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Institute of Kinetics and Catalysis, 1040 Sofia (Bulgaria) Summary The quantum-statistical solid state approach developed in [4] for a description of the d electron localization in transition metal oxides is briefly summarized and its possible application in catalysis is discussed. Some new possibilities for a choice of the optimal crystal fragment modeling the active site area are pointed out in this respect. Introduction The peculiar behaviour of the d electrons in transition metal oxides is of significant interest for catalysis as well as for many other fields of re- search. The experimental data indicate that the addition of a small amount of promoter or inhibitor changes considerably the activity of oxide catalysts. This means that long range solid state effects might take place at certain stages of the catalytic process. Therefore, to understand the behaviour of these systems one should account for the interrelated local and collective properties of their strongly correlated d electrons [1]. Important phenonema in this aspect are the electron charge fluctuations and the related localiza- tion-delocalization transitions. These phenomena appear to be related to the catalytic properties and chemical reactivity in general [2, 3]. An important problem in the theory of catalysis is how to model the active-site area and how to account for the lattice environment. The active site is strictly speaking an open quantum subsystem within the catalyst and one should account for the electron charge fluctuations in this crystal fragment. In another paper [4], we have developed a quantum-statistical model of the local electron charge fluctuations in oxides, in order to esti- mate the degree of the d electron localization. In the present work, we briefly summarize the basic statements of this model and comment on some results in the light of their possible application in catalysis. Results and discussions Let us briefly discuss some results obtained in [4] within the above- described model, which might be of interest for catalysis. For cubic lattices, the minimal possible S^MIN could be in principle the Wigner^Zeitz unit cell of the cation sublattice Uc. For a half-filled d-band, this state is meaningful only for very strong on-site correlations and corresponds to the Mott's picture of purely localized d electrons. However, the physical meaning of such a state is not clear enough to us, because the condition (7) requires in this case all inter-site correlators to be zero. For a half-filled d-band, the described AF state of maximum localization could be visualized as pairs of electrons with opposite spins, each pair being localized in a region of 2dVc (Fig. 2). It is well known that the notion of electron pairs and single valence electrons are very useful in the theory of chemical reactivity. In our opinion, similar notions such as that introduced in the present approach could be used in the description of the active sites in catalysts. Conclusions A model of the d electron localization in oxides is described, which offers a possible way to account for the interrelated local and collective effects in these catalysts. A new state of maximum electron localization in the sense of eqn. (8) is obtained. In this state the local behaviour of \2(2dUc) is interrelated with collective magnetic interactions. Let us point out in this respect, that even for the Mott insulators the embedded single cation re- presentation of the active site area may not be the best choice, if the condi- tion of minimum charge fluctuations is used as an additional criterion. Instead, the embedded cluster containing 2'^ unit cells appears to be more efficient, but only if the cluster properties are determined well above the mean-field limit. To proceed further one should combine in a proper way the solid state description with local quantum-chemical methods. The basic equations (1) and (3) could be related to the density functional theory and a general Green's function approach [II], which is a subject of a further research. References 1 T. M. Rice, Z.
